intro: Marsea persicifolia, commonly known as the peachleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves that resemble peach leaves, hence its common name. It produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Marsea persicifolia is often found in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
